metadata.product: Fitbit Versa 4 Fitness Smartwatch with Daily Readiness

transcript.speaker: **Interview
transcript.text: Fitbit Versa 4 Customer Feedback**

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** Emily, Corporate Representative, Fitbit

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Onyx, Customer ---

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Hi Onyx, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Emily, and I'm part of the product feedback team here at Fitbit. We really value hearing directly from our users, and your recent review of the Versa 4 caught our attention. We appreciate your honest feedback.

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Oh, hi Emily. No problem at all. Happy to help. I, uh, I think it's important for companies to hear what their customers are actually experiencing, so I'm glad to chat.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Absolutely. Your insights are invaluable as we strive to improve our products. To start, could you perhaps just elaborate a little on your overall experience with the Versa 4 since you first purchased it? You mentioned in your review it was your "first entry into the smartwatch world."

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Yeah, absolutely. So, as you said, it was my first foray into smartwatches. I hadn't really felt the need for one before, but I was getting more into fitness, especially running around the city, and, you know, just generally trying to be more mindful of my health. The Versa 4, on paper, seemed like a great balance of features and price. I really liked the idea of having fitness tracking, GPS for runs, and contactless payments all on my wrist. It felt like a solid step up from just using my phone for everything.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That makes a lot of sense. And what specifically drew you to the Versa 4 over other smartwatches you might have considered at that price point, or even just other fitness trackers?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that's a good question. I actually did a fair bit of research. For me, it came down to Fitbit's reputation for accurate fitness tracking, honestly. I'd heard good things from friends who had older Fitbits. And then, like I said, the promise of built-in GPS and Fitbit Pay was a huge draw. As someone in New York, being able to tap and go, or track a run without my phone, sounded incredibly convenient. Plus, the aesthetic was pretty sleek, and the price point was, you know, approachable for a first-time user who wasn't ready to commit to something like an Apple Watch right away.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** I understand. Reputation and those key features certainly make it appealing. You mentioned the "basic health monitoring" was a strong point for you. Could you tell me a bit more about which aspects of that you found most useful or effective?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Oh, definitely. The core fitness tracking – steps, heart rate, and especially sleep tracking – has been really consistent and reliable. I wear it pretty much all day and night. The app itself is actually quite good; the dashboard is visually clear, and seeing my trends over time, like my average heart rate or sleep stages, is genuinely helpful. It gives me a good baseline understanding of my general activity and how well I'm recovering. For that fundamental stuff, it truly does what it says on the tin. And it’s comfortable too, which, you know, for an all-day device, that's a big deal. The screen is also bright and easy to read, even when I'm outside.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That’s excellent to hear that the core tracking and user experience with the app are meeting your expectations. However, your review also highlighted some significant frustrations, particularly with the GPS and Fitbit Pay. Let's dive a bit deeper into the GPS issue first. Can you describe a typical scenario where you've encountered problems with it?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Yeah, absolutely. So, I mostly use it for outdoor runs and sometimes long walks. I live in the city, but I often head to Central Park or along the waterfront. Before I head out, I always try to let it acquire a signal, right? But it just takes *forever*. I'll be standing there, ready to go, stretching, and it's still searching. Sometimes, I'll wait a good three, four, even five minutes, and I just give up and start running. Then, later, I check the map in the app, and it's either completely inaccurate, or it's only tracked part of my route, or just… nothing at all.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That sounds incredibly frustrating, especially when you're geared up and ready to go. Does this happen consistently, or only in certain areas?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** It's pretty consistent, to be honest. I’d say at least 70-80% of the time, I have some issue. It doesn't seem to matter if I'm in a wide-open space like the park or near buildings. You'd think a major city like New York would have robust GPS coverage, but the Versa 4 just struggles. It’s a huge letdown because, as a buyer, I rely on data, and when I want to track my precise routes and distances, that's what I expect. It really undermines the point of having built-in GPS. I've gone back to sometimes just carrying my phone, which defeats the purpose.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** I can certainly see how that would diminish the value of a key feature for you. And when you do manage to get a lock, have you ever noticed it losing the signal mid-activity?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Oh, yeah, absolutely. That happens too. I'll start, it seems like it's connected, and then I'll look down ten minutes later, and it’s showing it’s searching again, or the distance suddenly jumps or changes oddly. It's like, what's the point if I can't trust the data? I want to see consistent splits and accurate total distances. It makes setting PRs or even just comparing runs really difficult.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Thank you for that detailed explanation, Onyx. That gives us a much clearer picture. Now, moving on to Fitbit Pay, you described it as "hit-or-miss." Could you share some specific instances or types of merchants where you’ve experienced issues?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Right, Fitbit Pay. Ugh. It's almost worse than the GPS because it puts me on the spot in public. I’ve tried using it at my local grocery store, coffee shops, even some subway kiosks where they accept contactless. Sometimes it works fine, maybe like 40% of the time? But the other 60%, it just… doesn't. I'll hold my watch to the terminal, and nothing. I try again, adjust the angle, nothing. I've had cashiers looking at me, a line forming behind me, and I just end up fumbling for my physical card or pulling out my phone. It's not the seamless, quick payment experience I was expecting at all.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That's definitely not the convenient experience we aim for. Do you find it fails more often with specific types of payment terminals, or does it seem quite random?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Hmm, good question. I haven't noticed a pattern with terminal types, to be honest. It seems pretty random. It might work at my deli one day and then not the next. Or it works at the Starbucks by my office, but not the one down the street. It’s just so inconsistent that I’ve mostly stopped relying on it. I still try sometimes, hoping it’ll work, but I always have a backup ready now. It’s a shame because the idea of leaving my wallet at home and just going for a run with my watch, and grabbing a coffee after, was a big part of why I bought it.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** I can understand how that inconsistency would really undermine its utility for daily use. You also mentioned that the screen seems quite prone to scratches. Could you tell me a little bit about that? When did you first notice them, and what kind of activities were you doing?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Yeah, the screen. I mean, I'm not, like, *rough* with my devices. I work as a buyer, so I'm often in meetings, traveling to suppliers, and, you know, just day-to-day city life. It's not like I'm doing extreme sports or anything. I first noticed a small scuff after maybe a month or so. And now, after a few months, there are definitely a few noticeable scratches, not deep gouges, but enough to be distracting when the light hits it. It's just... disappointing for a device that's supposed to be worn all the time and handle daily life. I would have expected a more durable screen material.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That’s fair feedback, especially for a device designed for active use. And then, finally, regarding the "Daily Readiness Score" being behind a subscription paywall after the trial, what's your perspective on that?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Oh, that one. It's a minor annoyance, but it adds up. When I saw it advertised, I thought, "Okay, that's a cool feature." It was part of the initial draw. You get the trial, and it's actually pretty insightful, right? It tells you if you should push hard or take it easy. Then, boom, it's gone unless you pay. It just feels a bit... nickel-and-diming. It feels like a core metric that should be part of the overall experience, especially since I've already purchased the device. It's like buying a car and then being told a key diagnostic feature requires a monthly fee.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** I appreciate your frankness, Onyx. Your perspective on that being a core feature, not an add-on, is valuable. Considering these challenges, if you were to look at alternatives now, what kind of features or reliability would be most important to you in a different smartwatch?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Honestly, reliability, above all else. I need the GPS to lock quickly and stay connected. And if a device offers contactless payments, it needs to work consistently, every single time. As a buyer, I value efficiency and functionality. If it says it does something, it needs to *actually* do it well. I'd also probably look for something with a more durable screen. I'm willing to pay a bit more for a device that delivers on its promises, even if it means moving away from Fitbit. The core fitness tracking is great, but the advanced features just don't stand up.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That’s very clear. So, if we could wave a magic wand and instantly improve the Versa 4, what would be the top two or three things you'd change or enhance?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Magic wand, huh? Okay. Number one, definitely the GPS. It needs to be faster at acquiring a signal and much more reliable during activities. Two, Fitbit Pay has to be flawless. Seriously, 100% reliable. And three, I'd say a more scratch-resistant screen. And maybe, just maybe, include the Daily Readiness Score as part of the initial purchase. That would make a huge difference in my overall satisfaction.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Those are very concrete suggestions, Onyx, thank you. You mentioned earlier that you hadn't used a smartwatch before the Versa 4. What about other methods of tracking your fitness? Did you use phone apps, or perhaps nothing at all before this?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Before this, it was pretty basic. I'd use my phone's built-in tracker for steps, and for runs, I’d just use a basic running app, but that meant carrying my phone, which I was trying to avoid. For sleep, it was really just guesswork, paying attention to how I felt. So, the Versa 4 definitely introduced me to a lot of new data and insights, which is why the core tracking is so appreciated. It's just the *smart* part that hasn't quite delivered.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Understood. So, the Versa 4 did elevate your awareness and data collection in a positive way. Given everything we've discussed today – the positives of the core tracking and app experience, balanced against the frustrations with GPS, Fitbit Pay, and screen durability – how would you describe your overall value perception of the Versa 4 now?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that's tricky. Initially, I thought it was good value for the price, given the feature set it promised. Now, it feels less so. For the basic tracking, it’s decent value, but if I'm paying for "smart" features that don't consistently work, then the value proposition drops considerably. I mean, if I could separate it, I’d say the basic tracker is worth it, but the "smartwatch" premium doesn’t feel justified right now. I ended up paying for features I can't reliably use.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That's a very clear way to put it, Onyx. Thank you. And thinking about recommending this product to a friend or colleague, particularly someone like yourself who might be looking for their first smartwatch, how likely would you be to recommend the Fitbit Versa 4 on a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is "not at all likely" and 10 is "extremely likely"?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** (pauses) On a scale of 1 to 10... I'd probably say a 5. Maybe a 6, on a good day. It's really hard, because if someone just wants basic step counting and sleep tracking, I’d say go for it. It's comfortable, the app is good. But if they're looking for what I was looking for – reliable GPS, seamless payments, a truly 'smart' experience – then I'd have to tell them about my frustrations. I’d caution them that it might over-promise and under-deliver on those specific fronts. It's just too inconsistent for me to give it a strong recommendation for its full feature set.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** That's a very honest assessment, Onyx, and incredibly helpful. We truly appreciate you taking the time to share your detailed experiences and insights with us today. Your feedback, especially on the GPS and Fitbit Pay reliability, is precisely what we need to hear to make meaningful improvements. Is there anything else you'd like to add or any other feedback you think would be important for us to know?

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** No, I think we covered everything pretty thoroughly. Just hope this helps you guys make it better. The potential is there, it's just about delivering on those promises.

transcript.speaker: **Emily
transcript.text: ** Thank you again, Onyx. Your feedback is invaluable. We'll be sure to pass all of this along to our product development teams. Have a great rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: **Onyx
transcript.text: ** You too, Emily. Thanks. ---
